segment.source: Help your users be more productive by letting them view multiple independent parts of your app in separate windows.
segment.target: Help your users be more productive by letting them view multiple independent parts of your app in separate windows.

segment.source: Show multiple views for an app
segment.target: Show multiple views for an app

segment.source: Show multiple views for an app
segment.target: Show multiple views for an app

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You can help your users be more productive by letting them view multiple independent parts of your app in separate windows.
segment.target: You can help your users be more productive by letting them view multiple independent parts of your app in separate windows.

segment.source: A typical example is an e-mail app where the main UI shows the list of emails and a preview of the selected e-mail.
segment.target: A typical example is an e-mail app where the main UI shows the list of emails and a preview of the selected e-mail.

segment.source: But users can also open messages in separate windows and view them side-by-side.
segment.target: But users can also open messages in separate windows and view them side-by-side.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: ApplicationViewSwitcher
segment.target: ApplicationViewSwitcher

segment.source: CreateNewView
segment.target: CreateNewView

segment.source: When you create multiple windows for an app, each window behaves independently.
segment.target: When you create multiple windows for an app, each window behaves independently.

segment.source: The taskbar shows each window separately.
segment.target: The taskbar shows each window separately.

segment.source: Users can move, resize, show, and hide app windows independently and can switch between app windows as if they were separate apps.
segment.target: Users can move, resize, show, and hide app windows independently and can switch between app windows as if they were separate apps.

segment.source: Each window operates in its own thread.
segment.target: Each window operates in its own thread.

segment.source: What is a view?
segment.target: What is a view?

segment.source: An app view is the 1:1 pairing of a thread and a window that the app uses to display content.
segment.target: An app view is the 1:1 pairing of a thread and a window that the app uses to display content.

segment.source: It's represented by a CoreApplicationView object.
segment.target: It's represented by a CoreApplicationView object.

segment.source: Views are managed by the CoreApplication object.
segment.target: Views are managed by the CoreApplication object.

segment.source: You call CoreApplication.CreateNewView to create aCoreApplicationView object.
segment.target: You call CoreApplication.CreateNewView to create aCoreApplicationView object.

segment.source: The CoreApplicationView brings together a CoreWindow and a CoreDispatcher (stored in the CoreWindow and Dispatcher properties).
segment.target: The CoreApplicationView brings together a CoreWindow and a CoreDispatcher (stored in the CoreWindow and Dispatcher properties).

segment.source: You can think of the CoreApplicationView as the object that the Windows Runtime uses to interact with the core Windows system.
segment.target: You can think of the CoreApplicationView as the object that the Windows Runtime uses to interact with the core Windows system.

segment.source: You typically don’t work directly with the CoreApplicationView.
segment.target: You typically don’t work directly with the CoreApplicationView.

segment.source: Instead, the Windows Runtime provides the ApplicationView class in the Windows.UI.ViewManagement namespace.
segment.target: Instead, the Windows Runtime provides the ApplicationView class in the Windows.UI.ViewManagement namespace.

segment.source: This class provides properties, methods, and events that you use when your app interacts with the windowing system.
segment.target: This class provides properties, methods, and events that you use when your app interacts with the windowing system.

segment.source: To work with an ApplicationView, call the static ApplicationView.GetForCurrentView method, which gets an ApplicationView instance tied to the current CoreApplicationView’s thread.
segment.target: To work with an ApplicationView, call the static ApplicationView.GetForCurrentView method, which gets an ApplicationView instance tied to the current CoreApplicationView’s thread.

segment.source: Likewise, the XAML framework wraps the CoreWindow object in a Windows.UI.XAML.Window object.
segment.target: Likewise, the XAML framework wraps the CoreWindow object in a Windows.UI.XAML.Window object.

segment.source: In a XAML app, you typically interact with the Window object rather than working directly with the CoreWindow.
segment.target: In a XAML app, you typically interact with the Window object rather than working directly with the CoreWindow.

segment.source: Show a new view
segment.target: Show a new view

segment.source: Before we go further, let's look at the steps to create a new view.
segment.target: Before we go further, let's look at the steps to create a new view.

segment.source: Here, the new view is launched in response to a button click.
segment.target: Here, the new view is launched in response to a button click.

segment.source: To show a new view
segment.target: To show a new view

segment.source: Call CoreApplication.CreateNewView to create a new window and thread for the view content.
segment.target: Call CoreApplication.CreateNewView to create a new window and thread for the view content.

segment.source: Track the Id of the new view.
segment.target: Track the Id of the new view.

segment.source: You use this to show the view later.
segment.target: You use this to show the view later.

segment.source: You might want to consider building some infrastructure into your app to help with tracking the views you create.
segment.target: You might want to consider building some infrastructure into your app to help with tracking the views you create.

segment.source: See the class in the MultipleViews sample for an example.
segment.target: See the class in the MultipleViews sample for an example.

segment.source: On the new thread, populate the window.
segment.target: On the new thread, populate the window.

segment.source: You use the CoreDispatcher.RunAsync method to schedule work on the UI thread for the new view.
segment.target: You use the CoreDispatcher.RunAsync method to schedule work on the UI thread for the new view.

segment.source: You use a lambda expression to pass a function as an argument to the RunAsync method.
segment.target: You use a lambda expression to pass a function as an argument to the RunAsync method.

segment.source: The work you do in the lambda function happens on the new view's thread.
segment.target: The work you do in the lambda function happens on the new view's thread.

segment.source: In XAML, you typically add a Frame to the Window's Content property, then navigate the Frame to a XAML Page where you've defined your app content.
segment.target: In XAML, you typically add a Frame to the Window's Content property, then navigate the Frame to a XAML Page where you've defined your app content.

segment.source: For more info, see Peer-to-peer navigation between two pages.
segment.target: For more info, see Peer-to-peer navigation between two pages.

segment.source: After the new Window is populated, you must call the Window's Activate method in order to show the Window later.
segment.target: After the new Window is populated, you must call the Window's Activate method in order to show the Window later.

segment.source: This work happens on the new view's thread, so the new Window is activated.
segment.target: This work happens on the new view's thread, so the new Window is activated.

segment.source: Finally, get the new view's Id that you use to show the view later.
segment.target: Finally, get the new view's Id that you use to show the view later.

segment.source: Again, this work is on the new view's thread, so ApplicationView.GetForCurrentView gets the Id of the new view.
segment.target: Again, this work is on the new view's thread, so ApplicationView.GetForCurrentView gets the Id of the new view.

segment.source: Show the new view by calling ApplicationViewSwitcher.TryShowAsStandaloneAsync.
segment.target: Show the new view by calling ApplicationViewSwitcher.TryShowAsStandaloneAsync.

segment.source: After you create a new view, you can show it in a new window by calling the ApplicationViewSwitcher.TryShowAsStandaloneAsync method.
segment.target: After you create a new view, you can show it in a new window by calling the ApplicationViewSwitcher.TryShowAsStandaloneAsync method.

segment.source: The viewId parameter for this method is an integer that uniquely identifies each of the views in your app.
segment.target: The viewId parameter for this method is an integer that uniquely identifies each of the views in your app.

segment.source: You retrieve the view Id by using either the ApplicationView.Id property or the ApplicationView.GetApplicationViewIdForWindow method.
segment.target: You retrieve the view Id by using either the ApplicationView.Id property or the ApplicationView.GetApplicationViewIdForWindow method.

segment.source: The main view
segment.target: The main view

segment.source: The first view that’s created when your app starts is called the main view.
segment.target: The first view that’s created when your app starts is called the main view.

segment.source: This view is stored in the CoreApplication.MainView property, and its IsMain property is true.
segment.target: This view is stored in the CoreApplication.MainView property, and its IsMain property is true.

segment.source: You don’t create this view; it’s created by the app.
segment.target: You don’t create this view; it’s created by the app.

segment.source: The main view's thread serves as the manager for the app, and all app activation events are delivered on this thread.
segment.target: The main view's thread serves as the manager for the app, and all app activation events are delivered on this thread.

segment.source: If secondary views are open, the main view’s window can be hidden – for example, by clicking the close (x) button in the window title bar - but its thread remains active.
segment.target: If secondary views are open, the main view’s window can be hidden – for example, by clicking the close (x) button in the window title bar - but its thread remains active.

segment.source: Calling Close on the main view’s Window causes an InvalidOperationException to occur.
segment.target: Calling Close on the main view’s Window causes an InvalidOperationException to occur.

segment.source: (Use Application.Exit to close your app.) If the main view’s thread is terminated, the app closes.
segment.target: (Use Application.Exit to close your app.) If the main view’s thread is terminated, the app closes.

segment.source: Secondary views
segment.target: Secondary views

segment.source: Other views, including all views that you create by calling CreateNewView in your app code, are secondary views.
segment.target: Other views, including all views that you create by calling CreateNewView in your app code, are secondary views.

segment.source: Both the main view and secondary views are stored in the CoreApplication.Views collection.
segment.target: Both the main view and secondary views are stored in the CoreApplication.Views collection.

segment.source: Typically, you create secondary views in response to a user action.
segment.target: Typically, you create secondary views in response to a user action.

segment.source: In some instances, the system creates secondary views for your app.
segment.target: In some instances, the system creates secondary views for your app.

segment.source: Note You can use the Windows assigned access feature to run an app in kiosk mode.
segment.target: Note You can use the Windows assigned access feature to run an app in kiosk mode.

segment.source: When you do this, the system creates a secondary view to present your app UI above the lock screen.
segment.target: When you do this, the system creates a secondary view to present your app UI above the lock screen.

segment.source: App-created secondary views are not allowed, so if you try to show your own secondary view in kiosk mode, an exception is thrown.
segment.target: App-created secondary views are not allowed, so if you try to show your own secondary view in kiosk mode, an exception is thrown.

segment.source: Switch from one view to another
segment.target: Switch from one view to another

segment.source: You must provide a way for the user to navigate from a secondary window back to the main window.
segment.target: You must provide a way for the user to navigate from a secondary window back to the main window.

segment.source: To do this, use the ApplicationViewSwitcher.SwitchAsync method.
segment.target: To do this, use the ApplicationViewSwitcher.SwitchAsync method.

segment.source: You call this method from the thread of the window you're switching from and pass the view ID of the window you're switching to.
segment.target: You call this method from the thread of the window you're switching from and pass the view ID of the window you're switching to.

segment.source: When you use SwitchAsync, you can choose if you want to close the initial window and remove it from the taskbar by specifying the value of ApplicationViewSwitchingOptions.
segment.target: When you use SwitchAsync, you can choose if you want to close the initial window and remove it from the taskbar by specifying the value of ApplicationViewSwitchingOptions.
